properties.name: Madrid, Spain
properties.description: Posted by ChilmoeLocationTeen club for base kids in the 1960\'s.

Posted by ChilmoeFaifax, VAAnywhere in Fairfax you can find a good hangout, but my friend and I would go down to a creek and catch frogs with another one of my friends. We would also go far into sewers and forests and imagine what it would be like 1000 year before us. We would also make fantasies that we were people like Jeff Corwin or Steve Irwin, but we would get a lot of laughsbecause we would mess up and fall in the mud or something. So... if u decide to come down to fairfax, grab some old clothes, a shovel, a pair of gloves, and get down n\' dirty with the lizards.

properties.name: 3130 Lander Road
properties.description: Posted by ChilmoeThis was my address for 15 years, and for all of my teenage life. I was 17, a Senior in high school, getting close to graduating, but not yet admitted to college. It was the day before the ACT standardized tests. I\'d already taken the SATs, the SAT 2s, and the APs. It felt like I\'d been applying to college forever. My dad was out of town, and my mom always went to bed early and slept like a rock. So I snuck out of the house and drove over to Jason\'s house to hang out with him and Joel. We were three honors students in a basement, pilfering their parents\' booze. It was rare to be unsupervised for more than an hour or two back then. I guess we went a little nuts. Jason got so drunk I watched him throw up in the middle of a sentence. It took him completely by surprise. Joel made several phone calls to girls, with no success, and then curled up on the couch to pass out. I got in my car and drove home. It was freezing and snowy out, and I was drunk, so I drove the half-mile home carefully. When I got there, my dad\'s car was in the garage and the back door was locked. He had come home from his business trip and locked me out! The last thing I wanted to do was wake my parents up in the middle of the night, drunk, and confess what I\'d been up to the night before the ACTs. So I curled up in the back seat of my car and prayed for sleep. I wrapped myself tightly in my coat, but it was too cold to sleep. I marched up to the front door, held my breath, and rang the doorbell. I could imagine my parents, groggy and annoyed, waking up and plodding downstairs. I waited, then rang again. Nothing. Bravely and resolutely facing my fate, I used the brass knocker. Usually this thing was loud enough to wake the dead. But knock as I might, I couldn\'t wake my parents up. I realized now that I wouldn\'t be rescued. I had to get into that house or I\'d freeze out there in the midwestern winter. And I had only myself to rely on. So I dragged the ladder out of the garage and stood it up on the lawn in front of the house. I climbed to the very top, onto the step that says "not a step," and managed to grab onto the house\'s gutter. I pulled myself up and scrambled up the icy roof. I took off my gloves and pressed my hands against the window to my room. I kept it unlocked, so if I could get enough traction on the icy roof... the window was open and I fell inside to warmth, carpeting, and glorious silence. Drunk though I still was, I remembered to go downstairs, unlock the back door, put the ladder back in the garage, and re-lock the back door. My mom woke me up a few hours later. I had a vicious hangover. I told her I had the flu. I took the ACTs anyway, and I got my first college acceptance letter -- with no ACTs required -- a week later. I never told my parents.

properties.name: Carvels Icecream
properties.description: Posted by ChilmoeCarvel\'s, Grand Avenue, Englewood, NJ When I was in high school, my friends Mary, Judy and I would sometimes sneak out of school go under the overpass and walk along Grand Avenue to reach our local Carvel\'s icecream stand. It was always such an enjoyable and satisfyingly bad thing to do. I don\'t know, maybe it\'s because I was raised a Catholic, that it really doesn\'t take much to be "bad" in a satisfying way. Ice cream is one of those ways, I guess. I\'d always get the same thing -- a chocolate marshmallow sundae with hot fudge sauce. It seems quite unfathomable now in retrospect that I was able to regularly consume such massive amounts of icecream.

properties.name: Caudy's Castle
properties.description: Posted by ChilmoeWhen I was a junior and senior in High school (1973-1974) We used to go camping at this bluff above the Cacopon River in West Virgina. No facilities; just a piece of land that someone within our rock climbing circle knew about. The owner was probably ignorant about his uninvited guests. Eventually, with liability in mind, the place was place off limits. Most incredible showing of the Milky Way I\'ve ever seen from the rocky outcrops high above the river. Spelunking nearby. One time we were not prepared for drop in temperature. Because some of us turned out to be uncomfortable in the caves, we didn\'t have the option of taking refuge within their warmth at night. Instead, we slept about 6 to a pup tent trying to stay warm with each other\'s body heat. I remember my feet sticking out from under covers and out the pup tent wall (before the days of tent floors). I don\'t remember ever being so unprepared ever again. My experiences at Caudy\'s Castle were pretty much an expression of my need to be outdoor in the most primitive of ways. This is when I am at peace and feel most myself. When I have time, I\'ll post an entry for my trips to the Grand Canyon....21 day trip down the river in a kayak and an overnight hike to the bottom of the gorge from the South side.

properties.name: French River, Minnesota
properties.description: Posted by Chilmoeduluth, mnFrench River - This river saved my sanity all through the four years I lived on its banks while in high school. All seasons, all hours of the day and night, a presence without self that somehow helped define my self.

properties.name: Laurie's hood 1983
properties.description: Posted by ChilmoeOn a Friday night in June, while hanging out with friends at the beach near the Aquarium, I looked up at the moon and suddenly I "knew" that everything is OK just as it is. I was in high school at the time and like most teenagers I worried about everything. It was at that moment, while looking up at the moon, that I was liberated from worry.

properties.name: Matt's Solitude
properties.description: Posted by System Hey -- I grew up in the midst of some corn fields outside Monee, Illinois. It was there, on the farm, that I would roam the fields, looking for arrowheads and fossils. This is where I found my solitude and this is where I forged my love for openness, quietness and solitude -- in essence, this is why I love wilderness.

properties.name: Mount Yale, Collegiate Peaks, CO
properties.description: Posted by ChilmoeBuena Vista, COA simple overnight backpacking trip. The boyfriend stayed below, he doesn\'t like hiking. The dark forest wall near my alpine camp frightens me; I can\'t see in and no sound comes out of it. I don\'t look at it. Something large strolls through my camp in the night. Walking alone on the trail I hear other people long before I see them. I\'m amazed that when I step several paces off the trail that they are so absorbed in themselves that they never see me. I\'m invisible in plain sight. I start too late for the peak; the afternoon storm stalks my steps. The ledge 300 feet below the top offers shelter from pummeling blasts of snow and stinging rain. Thunder rumbles as light flashes to fill the entire world - one thousand nothing -I am IN the storm and no one knows I am but me and I can not stop smiling.

properties.name: fairfax
properties.description: Posted by Systemthis place is not too congested and not too rural, fairfax is a perfect comprimise between extreme cities that exist today. With many places to go and jsut hang or play it is perfect for many teenagers such as myself.

properties.name: ocean city, md
properties.description: Posted by SystemaddressSaturday mornings during high school and college leaving at 6:00 a.m., driving 3 hours through eastern shore water towns and cornfields. Driving to the ocean, its sounds, its smells, its textures. Spending the day people watching, body surfing, and sunning. Drive home that night always required a stop at an eastern shore church barbeque. Finally the shower that took away the sand and salt.
